awd_titl_txt: Monetary Policy, Demographics and the Business Cycle
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

Understanding how aging affects macroeconomic policy becomes increasingly important as baby-boomers retire in the U.S. and there are shifts in the age-composition of population in the world. This project documents how changes in age distribution affects the response of incomes and employment to monetary policy. Preliminary results indicate that states with many young residents appear less sensitive to monetary policy, whereas states with many middle-aged residents appear more sensitive. The project explores the underlying reasons of such differences and uses these results to construct models of the economy that more accurately reflect the demographic changes observed. The research improves the understanding of how monetary policy impacts the economy in relation to demographic changes. Thus, the project helps the Federal Reserve and the private sector anticipate changes to the economy brought about by an aging US population. Similarly, the research has implications for monetary policies of other economies where there are shifts in age-composition. 

The project uses the U.S. states as a laboratory to explore how age distribution influences monetary policy. The proposed research looks at how state level variables such as income and employment respond to monetary policy initiatives. These responses are then related to the age composition of the state, while controlling for other reasons that states may differ. Preliminary results indicate that incomes of all age groups respond more to interest rates in a state with more middle-aged residents. These preliminary results indicate that what matters most to an individual is not their own age, but the age distribution of the state in which they live. The proposal further looks at the mechanism that drives this sensitivity. Potential mechanisms include greater sensitivity of construction and proprietor?s income to the proportion of the middle aged and differences in the elasticity of demand across age groups. In the theoretical component of the proposal, empirical results are used to construct models of the economy that accurately reflect the demographic influences we observe. Explicitly considering demographics improves the understanding of monetary policy transmission and has broader implications on the economy as population ages and baby boomers retire.

por.por_cntn:
Macroeconomics considers the economy as a whole and often ignores the underlying demographic structure. This project considered several ways in which the demographic structure of the economy might influence policy in general and monetary policy in particular.

The first phase of the project considered how the age structure of an economy might affect the transmission of monetary policy. In our paper “Age Structure and the Impact of Monetary Policy,” published in the American Economic Journal: Macroeconomics, we exploited variation in the response of US states to monetary policy shocks to study how the impact of monetary policy varies with the age structure of the population. We found that the economy’s response is weaker, the greater is the share of the population under 35 years of age and stronger the greater the share between 40 and 65. We found that all age groups become more responsive to monetary policy shocks when the proportion of the middle-aged increases. We considered a number of explanations for this phenomenon and concluded that the evidence is consistent with the important role that middle-aged entrepreneurs play in starting and expanding businesses in response to changes in interest rates.

Subsequent work has considered other demographic characteristics. Interestingly, we find that the impact of monetary policy is stronger in states in which the labor force participation of married women is greater. We argue that this may reflect variation in the influence of the “added worker effect” in which individuals enter the labor force when their partners lose their jobs. As more married women work, both partners become more attached to the labor force, the family gains income on average but loses the flexibility of having one partner enter the labor market when the other is unemployed. This loss of flexibility makes monetary policy more potent.

A separate line of research considered the social discount rate. In “Missing Participants, Missing Markets, and the Social Discount Rate: Borrowing Constraints, Intergenerational Transfers, Altruism, and the Desire for Legacy,” published in the Annual Reviews of Financial Economics, we evaluate the use of market interest rates to value social projects when some agents, such as future generations, do not participate in the market. The issue here is that market interest rates reflect the preferences of market participants. When market participants are missing, the average discount rate in the population may therefore differ from the market rate. We argue that when current market participants are missing, possibly due to borrowing constraints, the social discount rate tends to be above the market rate, whereas missing future market participants, such as future generations, tends to imply a social rate below the market rate. Nonetheless, a government with the ability to tax and make transfers across agents will generally wish to use the market interest rate as a guide to policy. We also provide several arguments for the use of a discount rate lower than the market rate that are robust to the availability of taxes and transfers. One is intrapersonal: Future selves discount the past, whereas current selves discount the future. Another is the desire for legacy.
